unicode.value:
Certificate in Early Childhood Development and Education
December 2015

Instructions to Candidates:

This question paper consists of TWO sections: A and B. Answer ALL the questions in section A and FOUR questions in section B. Answers to both sections A and B must be written in the spaces provided in this booklet.

SECTION A (40 marks)

Answer ALL the questions in this section.

Question 1

(a) State four factors to consider in order to preserve nutrients when preparing vegetables. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Use minimal water when cooking vegetables to prevent nutrient loss.
  • Avoid overcooking vegetables to retain their nutritional value.
  • Store vegetables in a cool, dry place to preserve their nutrients.
  • Use fresh vegetables whenever possible to maximize nutrient content.

(b) Highlight four ways of maintaining good health of a child at an ECDE centre. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Ensure regular handwashing to prevent the spread of germs.
  • Provide a balanced diet to support the child's growth and development.
  • Encourage regular physical activity to promote overall health.
  • Maintain a clean and safe environment to prevent accidents and infections.

Question 2

(a) State the uses of three improvised items of a First Aid kit in an ECDE centre. (3 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • A clean cloth can be used to stop bleeding or as a bandage.
  • A plastic bag can be used as an ice pack when filled with ice.
  • A piece of string can be used as a tourniquet in emergencies.

(b) State four measures a teacher may take to prevent the spread of respiratory tract infections among children in an ECDE centre. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Encourage children to cover their mouths when coughing or sneezing.
  • Ensure proper ventilation in the classroom.
  • Promote regular handwashing with soap and water.
  • Isolate children showing symptoms of respiratory infections.

Question 3

(a) Identify three factors that influence growth in children. (3 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Genetic factors inherited from parents.
  • Nutritional intake and diet.
  • Environmental factors such as access to healthcare and living conditions.

Question 4

(a) Define the term client as used in counselling. (1 mark)

Sample Answer:

A client is an individual who seeks professional help or guidance from a counsellor to address personal, emotional, or psychological issues.

(b) State four characteristics of congruence as a quality of a good counsellor. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Being genuine and authentic in interactions with clients.
  • Maintaining consistency between words and actions.
  • Being transparent and honest in communication.
  • Demonstrating self-awareness and emotional stability.

(c) Give five factors that may cause examination fever. (5 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Fear of failure or poor performance.
  • High expectations from parents or teachers.
  • Lack of adequate preparation for the exam.
  • Pressure to perform well in competitive environments.
  • Anxiety about the consequences of poor results.

SECTION B (60 marks)

Answer FOUR questions from this section.

Question 5

(a) Outline seven categories of people who should seek VCT services. (7 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Individuals engaging in unprotected sex.
  • People who have multiple sexual partners.
  • Individuals who share needles or syringes.
  • Pregnant women to prevent mother-to-child transmission.
  • Healthcare workers exposed to blood or bodily fluids.
  • People who have been sexually assaulted.
  • Individuals with symptoms of HIV/AIDS.

(b) Highlight four social factors that put women at risk of contracting HIV. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Gender inequality and lack of empowerment.
  • Cultural practices that promote early marriage.
  • Economic dependence on male partners.
  • Lack of access to education and healthcare.

(c) Explain two relationships between STIs and AIDS. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • STIs can increase the risk of HIV transmission due to open sores or inflammation.
  • People with STIs are more likely to engage in risky sexual behaviors, increasing the likelihood of HIV infection.

Question 6

(a) (i) State four symptoms of diarrhoea and vomiting among children. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Frequent loose or watery stools.
  • Nausea and vomiting.
  • Abdominal pain or cramps.
  • Dehydration, indicated by dry mouth or reduced urination.

(ii) Identify three ways of preventing diarrhoea and vomiting among children. (3 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Ensuring proper handwashing with soap and water.
  • Providing safe and clean drinking water.
  • Promoting breastfeeding for infants to boost immunity.

(b) Describe the procedure for treating a child who has been stung by a bee. (8 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Remove the stinger by scraping it off with a flat object.
  2. Wash the affected area with soap and water.
  3. Apply a cold compress to reduce swelling and pain.
  4. Monitor the child for signs of an allergic reaction, such as difficulty breathing or swelling of the face.
  5. Seek medical attention if an allergic reaction occurs.

Question 7

(a) State two strategies that can be used to promote community health. (2 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Health education campaigns to raise awareness about preventive measures.
  • Providing access to clean water and sanitation facilities.

(b) Give five reasons why counselling and testing for HIV and AIDS is important. (5 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Early detection allows for timely medical intervention.
  • Reduces the risk of transmitting the virus to others.
  • Provides emotional and psychological support to those affected.
  • Encourages behavior change to prevent further infections.
  • Helps in planning for future health and lifestyle adjustments.

(c) Explain four different ways through which poisoning may occur to a child at home. (8 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Ingestion of household chemicals or medications.
  • Inhalation of toxic fumes from cleaning products.
  • Skin contact with harmful substances like pesticides.
  • Accidental consumption of poisonous plants or berries.

Question 8

(a) Outline six factors that may affect normal development of a foetus. (6 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Maternal nutrition and diet during pregnancy.
  • Exposure to harmful substances like alcohol or tobacco.
  • Maternal health conditions such as diabetes or hypertension.
  • Infections during pregnancy, such as rubella or toxoplasmosis.
  • Genetic or chromosomal abnormalities.
  • Stress and emotional well-being of the mother.

(b) Identify five methods of modern food preservation that can be used in the home. (5 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Refrigeration to slow down bacterial growth.
  • Freezing to preserve food for longer periods.
  • Canning to seal food in airtight containers.
  • Drying or dehydrating to remove moisture.
  • Using preservatives like salt or sugar to inhibit microbial growth.

(c) State four ways of ensuring good hygiene when preparing food in the kitchen at an ECDE centre. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Washing hands thoroughly before handling food.
  • Keeping kitchen surfaces clean and sanitized.
  • Storing food at the correct temperature to prevent spoilage.
  • Using separate utensils for raw and cooked foods to avoid cross-contamination.

Question 9

(a) (i) Explain the meaning of educational guidance. (2 marks)

Sample Answer:

Educational guidance refers to the process of helping students make informed decisions about their education, career paths, and personal development.

(ii) Identify four advantages of educational guidance. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Helps students identify their strengths and interests.
  • Provides support in making career and academic choices.
  • Encourages personal and social development.
  • Reduces dropout rates by addressing students' needs and challenges.

(b) (i) Define substance abuse. (2 marks)

Sample Answer:

Substance abuse refers to the harmful or excessive use of drugs or alcohol, leading to physical, psychological, or social problems.

(ii) Give three reasons why the youth use drugs. (3 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Peer pressure and the desire to fit in with friends.
  • Curiosity and experimentation with new experiences.
  • Stress or emotional problems leading to self-medication.

(c) State four issues a counsellor would assist a client to establish during the exploration stage of counselling. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Identifying the client's main concerns or problems.
  • Exploring the client's feelings and emotions related to the issue.
  • Understanding the client's goals and expectations from counselling.
  • Assessing the client's readiness for change and commitment to the process.

© 2015 The Kenya National Examinations Council

Certificate in Early Childhood Development and Education
December 2017

Instructions to Candidates:

This question paper consists of TWO sections: A and B. Answer ALL the questions in section A and FOUR questions from section B. Answers to both sections A and B must be written in the spaces provided in this booklet.

SECTION A (40 marks)

Answer ALL the questions in this section.

Question 1

(a) Highlight three challenges of using the calendar method in family planning. (3 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Irregular menstrual cycles can make it difficult to predict fertile days.
  • Requires strict adherence to tracking and abstaining during fertile periods.
  • Not effective for women with hormonal imbalances or irregular ovulation.

(b) Give three signs and symptoms of measles. (3 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • High fever and cough.
  • Runny nose and red, watery eyes.
  • Rash that starts on the face and spreads to the rest of the body.

(c) Identify four ways in which maternal and child health care services can be made more accessible in rural areas of Kenya. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Establishing mobile clinics to reach remote areas.
  • Training community health workers to provide basic services.
  • Providing free or subsidized health care services.
  • Improving infrastructure such as roads and communication networks.

Question 2

(a) List four food nutrients that make up a balanced diet. (2 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Carbohydrates.
  • Proteins.
  • Fats.
  • Vitamins and minerals.

(b) State four food taboos that may affect the nutritional status of mothers and children. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Prohibiting pregnant women from eating certain nutritious foods.
  • Restricting children from consuming eggs or milk.
  • Beliefs that certain foods are harmful during specific life stages.
  • Cultural practices that limit the consumption of animal proteins.

(c) Identify four eating habits a teacher would emphasize to children during meal times in an ECDE centre. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Eating a variety of foods to ensure a balanced diet.
  • Chewing food properly to aid digestion.
  • Washing hands before and after meals.
  • Avoiding wastage of food.

Question 3

(a) (i) Give the meaning of first aid. (1 mark)

Sample Answer:

First aid is the immediate assistance given to a person who has been injured or suddenly taken ill before professional medical help is available.

(ii) Identify three qualities of a good first aider. (3 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Calmness under pressure.
  • Good communication skills.
  • Knowledge of basic first aid techniques.

(b) Identify four health services supported by UNICEF that promote Early Childhood Development Education in Kenya. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Immunization programs to prevent childhood diseases.
  • Nutrition programs to combat malnutrition.
  • Provision of clean water and sanitation facilities.
  • Health education campaigns for parents and caregivers.

Question 4

(a) Give the meaning of:

(i) Career guidance. (1 mark)

Sample Answer:

Career guidance is the process of helping individuals make informed decisions about their career paths and educational choices.

(ii) Conflict resolution. (1 mark)

Sample Answer:

Conflict resolution is the process of resolving disputes or disagreements between parties in a peaceful and constructive manner.

(b) State four issues that may require a counsellor to refer a learner in an ECDE centre for further assistance. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Severe emotional or behavioral problems.
  • Learning disabilities or developmental delays.
  • Signs of abuse or neglect.
  • Mental health issues such as anxiety or depression.

(c) Identify four behavioral signs that will alert an ECDE teacher that a child requires counselling. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Withdrawal from social interactions.
  • Aggressive or disruptive behavior.
  • Frequent crying or emotional outbursts.
  • Difficulty concentrating or completing tasks.

SECTION B (60 marks)

Answer FOUR questions from this section.

Question 5

(a) (i) Define the term weaning. (1 mark)

Sample Answer:

Weaning is the process of gradually introducing an infant to solid foods while reducing their dependence on breast milk or formula.

(ii) Explain three problems a baby is likely to experience during weaning. (6 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Digestive issues such as constipation or diarrhea.
  • Allergic reactions to new foods.
  • Refusal to eat solid foods due to unfamiliar textures or tastes.

(b) State four ways of enriching maize meal porridge for children in an ECDE centre. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Adding milk or milk powder for protein and calcium.
  • Mixing in mashed fruits for vitamins and natural sweetness.
  • Including groundnuts or peanut butter for healthy fats.
  • Adding eggs for additional protein and nutrients.

(c) Explain the roles of two minerals whose intake is required in higher proportions during pregnancy. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Iron: Essential for the production of hemoglobin to prevent anemia and support fetal growth.
  • Calcium: Important for the development of the baby's bones and teeth, and to maintain the mother's bone health.

Question 6

(a) (i) Apart from the teacher, name four other caregivers who provide safety and care for children. (2 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Parents or guardians.
  • Nannies or babysitters.
  • Relatives or extended family members.
  • Community health workers.

(ii) Explain three roles of a teacher as a caregiver in early childhood development. (6 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Providing a safe and nurturing environment for children.
  • Supporting children's emotional and social development.
  • Encouraging learning through play and structured activities.

(b) Outline the procedure an ECDE teacher would follow to remove an insect from a child’s ear. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Stay calm and reassure the child.
  2. Tilt the child's head to the side to allow the insect to crawl out.
  3. If the insect does not come out, use a small amount of oil (e.g., olive oil) to suffocate the insect.
  4. Seek medical assistance if the insect remains lodged in the ear.

(c) Highlight three ways that may not transmit HIV/AIDS. (3 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Sharing utensils or eating food prepared by someone with HIV.
  • Hugging or shaking hands with an infected person.
  • Using the same toilet or bathroom facilities.

Question 7

(a) Outline the first four stages of the counselling process. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  1. Establishing rapport and building trust with the client.
  2. Identifying the client's issues and concerns.
  3. Exploring the client's feelings and emotions.
  4. Setting goals and developing a plan of action.

(b) Describe five non-verbal behaviors a counsellor should observe when attending to a client. (5 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Facial expressions, such as smiles or frowns.
  • Body posture, such as slouching or leaning forward.
  • Eye contact, or lack thereof.
  • Gestures, such as hand movements or nodding.
  • Tone of voice and speech patterns.

(c) Explain three ways in which prescription drugs may be abused. (6 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Taking higher doses than prescribed.
  • Using someone else's prescription medication.
  • Using drugs for non-medical purposes, such as to get high.

Question 8

(a) (i) Give the meaning of Primary Health Care (PHC). (2 marks)

Sample Answer:

Primary Health Care (PHC) is the first level of contact individuals have with the health care system, providing essential health services that are accessible, affordable, and community-based.

(ii) Describe five principles of Primary Health Care (PHC). (5 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Equitable distribution of health services.
  • Community participation in health care decisions.
  • Focus on prevention and health promotion.
  • Use of appropriate technology and resources.
  • Multi-sectoral collaboration to address health determinants.

(b) Complete the immunization table below. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

Vaccine Mode of Administration Disease Immunized Against
BCG Injection on the upper arm Tuberculosis
DPT Injection on outer right thigh Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus
OPV Oral/through the mouth Polio
Measles Injection on the upper arm Measles

(c) Explain two measures to take to prevent malaria in the community. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Use of insecticide-treated bed nets to prevent mosquito bites.
  • Elimination of stagnant water to reduce mosquito breeding sites.

Question 9

(a) State four danger signs that may require an expectant mother to seek medical attention. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Severe abdominal pain or cramping.
  • Vaginal bleeding or discharge.
  • Severe headaches or blurred vision.
  • Swelling of the hands, feet, or face.

(b) Identify four cultural practices that promote the spread of HIV infection. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Female Genital Mutilation (FGM) using unsterilized tools.
  • Wife inheritance, where a widow is inherited by a relative of her deceased husband.
  • Polygamous marriages with multiple sexual partners.
  • Traditional practices involving shared cutting instruments, such as circumcision rituals.

(c) (i) Give three reasons why bottle feeding is discouraged. (3 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Increased risk of infections due to improper sterilization of bottles.
  • Lack of essential antibodies found in breast milk, which protect the baby from diseases.
  • Higher cost and inconvenience compared to breastfeeding.

(ii) Explain two economic causes of malnutrition in Kenya. (4 marks)

Sample Answer:

  • Poverty: Many families cannot afford nutritious food due to low income.
  • High food prices: The cost of healthy food options is often too high for low-income households.
